content:
Anyone have some background on the motivation for this operation? I note that it isn't part of the FHIR base profile for DocumentReference and based on my reading of http://www.fhir.org/guides/argonaut/r2/StructureDefinition-argo-documentreference.html it is intended as a not-very-simplified way to execute a query with a CCD type specifier. I don't see how this adds any real value.

UPDATE: Reading further (http://www.fhir.org/guides/argonaut/r2/OperationDefinition-docref.html) I find this qualification: "The server SHOULD return at least all references for documents that it has made available in a document indexing system. This is the same as a simple query (GET [base]/DocumentReference?patient=[id]). This operaton differs from a simple query in that DocumentReferences may be created ‘on-the-fly’ in response to this operation.”

So $docRef exists to support the on-demand use case only?
Yes, because "on the fly" doesn't necessarily persist and is a special use case that CCDS required

And is behavior that would be a bit surprising if you just queried DocumentReference by patient id.

Note: I believe this is going to be part of a PSS to move some of the work done on DocumentReference from CCDS use cases into the US-FHIR-Core profiles (@Brett Marquard @Eric Haas )
on demand documents is not a US specific thing
Yes, this will be included in the latest PSS --
I don't think there is anything US Specific other than the direct reference to the DocumentReference profile
@Peter Bernhardt The way it's currently written it says both
/DocumentReference/$docref is the name of the operation? Well that's not very descriptive.
agree, open to suggestions
$include-transient?
retracting that -- why should we create new terminology? how about $include-on-demand?
$on-demand? :)
naming is hard

I thought about $on-demand, but that might confuse people who are only expecting on-demand be included.

(I wonder if there are other places that there might be a need to return transient resources, and if there is a need for a more generalized operation, or an element in the base resources that says "don't bother trying to retrieve this again, it won't exist." (with an element, you could use a regular search to say, "?....transient=true" or "?...transient=true,false" which would be an indication to return any transient resources you were capable of generating.)
$otf
or $generate
Definitely not $otf :)

Can we get this work done in IHE where the core concept exists in XDS and thus needs a MHD (FHIR) solution? I am not against this solution, but am not sure it is the best solution. It is definitely an international need

IHE (ITI) is right now taking new work item proposals ... I am newly elected co-chair of the ITI planning... https://healthcaresecprivacy.blogspot.com/2017/08/ihe-it-infrastructure-planning-co-chair.html

Please... lets stop unnecessary duplicate standards... Argonaut use of DocumentReference benefited by my efforts to bring this from IHE. There is no conflict with IHE-MHD, but there is perceived dissonance in the marketspace by continued duplicate work.
